Journal Title: Ethics & the Environment
Article Title: Martin Heidegger: Antinaturalistic Critic of Technological Modernity
Publisher: The Guilford Press
Issue: ete.2010.15.issue-1
Date: January 25, 2003
Author(s): Crowley Thomas
Abstract: Evaluative terms are a crucial part of the environmental discourse. These terms, and the evaluative frameworks in which they are imbedded, serve as important guides to action. “Natural,” a term commonly used as a positive evaluation, is problematic because it can both justify unfair social relations and obscure the connections between humans and the rest of nature. “Sustainable,” another popular term, is extremely malleable, and is too often elaborated in frameworks that are neither socially nor ecologically responsible. The term “sustainable” is sometimes used in the framework of ecosystem health, but even this approach can fail to highlight the interconnectedness of social and ecological systems. The framework of ecosocial flourishing, introduced in this article, is better suited for highlighting the interconnected nature of the world and for drawing attention to questions of environmental justice. Evaluative terms (like “natural”) and frameworks (like “ecosocial flourishing”) are part of larger narratives that help people make sense of their interactions with, and emotional responses to, the non-human world.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.2979/ete.2010.15.1.69 journal-article-10.2979_ete.2010.15.1.69.xml

Journal Title: jml: Journal of Modern Literature
Article Title: “Materialism and Aesthetics: Paul de Man's
Publisher: New Directions
Issue: jmodelite.35.issue-3
Date: Oct. 1, 1991
Author(s): Carlson Celia
Abstract: Recent scholarship has given considerable attention to lyric poetry as a form of sensuous knowledge. This approach emphasizes the corporeal origins of poetry, its genesis in the body or in language viewed as material. The question of sensuous knowledge is central to the larger theoretical issue of modernity itself, in which lyric holds a central yet ambiguous status. The question of sensuous knowledge is ultimately a question of meaning. However, modern thought — thought pertaining to “modernity” — is fundamentally circular. This would seem to establish an epistemological impasse for aesthetics. But I argue that this circularity offers an important, and necessary, way to limit knowledge and thereby ground an ethical subjectivity. My essay places formalism at the heart of sensuous knowledge. In this essay I develop an account of the importance of abstraction in sensuous knowledge by way of Kant's concept of Darstellung, “presentation [of sensory experience].” The “presentation” is the object as it has undergone a structural process of internalization and been made available for psychic use as meaning; that requires a recognition of loss. Where this is important for literature is that twentieth-century American poetry frequently uses very personal images of family life as a way of conveying sincerity about corporeal experience. I use this discussion of circularity in modern aesthetic thought to argue that there is a risk to taking shortcuts to meaning through images of the material bodies of children. In these contemporary poems by Gary Snyder, Sharon Olds and Rita Dove, the poets reject loss in favor of a very modern “affirmation” of the material. But affirmation and the visual image as a sign of affirmation cannot alone bind meaning to us. That meaning must be internalized through theworkof poetic presentation.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.2979/jmodelite.35.3.158 journal-article-10.2979_jmodelite.35.3.158.xml

Journal Title: The F. Scott Fitzgerald Review
Article Title: “Nature and Optics in the Great Gatsby.”
Publisher: Penguin
Issue: fscotfitzrevi.12.1.issue-1
Date: 10 1, 1989
Author(s): Salmose Niklas
Abstract: One such recurring motif is the use of flowers in general and pink roses in particular. They connect the reader's experiences from the first part with the second part in a way that he, perhaps subconsciously, is reminded of that first experience and the happiness of that textual memory. Langman writes that this motif functions “as a simple unifying device, reminding us of one scene as we read another” (43). There are several rose motifs in the opening of the novel. The first that attracts Nick's attention at the Buchanans’ home is the rose garden: “a half acre of deep pungent roses.” Later, Nick and Tom enter “into a bright rosy-colored space” (7); they look through “a rosy-colored porch” (11); and Daisy (herself named after a flower) calls Nick “a rose, an absolute rose” (14).
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/fscotfitzrevi.12.1.0067 journal-article-10.5325_fscotfitzrevi.12.1.0067.xml

Journal Title: Interdisciplinary Literary Studies
Article Title: “History and Tragedy.”
Publisher: Harper and Row
Issue: intelitestud.16.2.issue-2
Date: 9 1, 1971
Author(s): Eze Chielozona
Abstract: The picture painted is that of a guest asking for accommodation. But we learn that the speaker is a child, and therefore his plea is existential; he wants to live and to thrive. The speaker's clan is representative of the larger world. He pleads with the world for a chance to grow. “I am not Dekuah; let me live” (9). “I am not Dekuah” appears five times in the seven stanzas of the poem, underscoring the speaker's resolve to live. This anaphora draws attention to the precariousness of the situation that children, and, indeed everyone else, was facing at that time. People were making peace with the fact that children were not surviving childhood. As child soldiers, even some of the children had turned against their parents. It is in this context that the speaker announced that he is not Dekuah.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/intelitestud.16.2.0282 journal-article-10.5325_intelitestud.16.2.0282.xml

Journal Title: Journal of Africana Religions
Article Title: What Is Africa to Me?
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jafrireli.1.1.issue-1
Date: 1 1, 2013
Abstract: The term transculturation was first used by the Cuban sociologist Fernando Ortiz to describe the existence and relationships between the indigenous African and Spanish populations in Cuba.32 He shows how these groups adapted to each other in modes of language, music, art, and agricultural work. The contemporary usage of the term has been enhanced by Mary Louise Pratt's attention to the meaning of travel in the transcultural situation.33 For Pratt, transculturation brings into being “contact zones” within which cultures meet, clash, and grapple. According to Pratt the zones give expression to an improvisational modality. These contact zones have taken place for a long time over almost all the geographical spaces of the earth. The adaptation and improvisations coincidental to situations of this kind have to do with the pace and rhythm of the dominating culture, the number and variety of cultures in contact, and the rhetoric of occupation.34
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jafrireli.1.1.0091 journal-article-10.5325_jafrireli.1.1.0091.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: The Plight of Ethics
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: Following this line of thought, we might wonder why leading up to the execution of Davis on September 21 abolitionists around the world rallied and protested trying to save his life, while at the same time on that very Wednesday evening little attention was paid to another execution, that of Lawrence Brewer, the infamous Texan who tied a black hitchhiker to the back of his truck and dragged him to death. He, too, proclaimed his innocence of the murder of James Byrd Jr. until his dying breath. Reportedly there were celebrations of Brewer's death by people who thought that he got what he deserved for his heinous racist hate crime. The outcry against the execution of Davis at the very same moment as the jubilance over the execution of Brewer could be seen as a strangely perverse symptom of the history of racism trying to put things right by rejoicing over one execution while raging over the other. Even after the executions, there were comparisons between Davis refusing a last meal in order to pray silently with friends and family and Brewer ordering several pizzas, cheeseburgers, pounds of BBQ, tacos, and other comfort food and then refusing to eat it, which disgusted some commentators and prison officials, who suggested that Brewer was not only undignified but also ungrateful.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0118 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0118.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Phenomenology
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: If it is true that love and the invocation of the second-personal pronoun target what the other person refers to with “I,” then we may consider that this is likewise not a property or a quality. Indeed this is necessarily so because what “I” refers to is “myself as myself,” and in so doing I achieve the per seknowing to which Brentano called attention. But quite in opposition to another strain in his thought, I propose that I need no third-personal, nonindexical, descriptive terms or properties to achieve this knowing. Prior to the achievement of “I” as a reflective intentional act, but also in the reflective indexical achievement of “I,” I am aware uniquely of myself, and I don't have to be aware of anything else but myself to achieve this. 28
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0222 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0222.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: French Poststructuralism
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: We find one of the major conditions for this diversification in the growth of SPEP's membership and the number of participants on the programs. In its early days, when thirty or fewer people attended meetings, most sessions could be plenary, and people could expect during the conference conversations on papers and commentaries that everyone had heard. But as the members and range of interest increased, the number of sessions also increased to accommodate the volume of submissions and to lessen conflict with those who felt that their interests had inadequate representation on the programs. Growth brought with it complex new political problems involving incompatible points of view as well as gender and generational differences. The consequences of this growth included diversification and restructuring of the programs, an increased suspicion of and attention to the Executive Committee, an intensified alertness to exclusions, and the formation of a dynamic organization that had less and less to do with its name. These conditions helped to give birth to a new organizational arrangement where centralized power became increasingly fragmented. There was no one mission. There were multiple missions that gave rise to conflict and needed negotiation to function collaboratively, if often with suspicion of each other. But the revolution was not over.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0299 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0299.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Philosophy of Technology
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: 1979. I list this date because it was the year several books were published that changed the interpretation of technologies for our era. Laboratory Life, by Bruno Latour and Steve Woolgar (1979), shifted the interpretation of both science and technology to a praxis-oriented and materially sensitive interpretation. Latour followed up withScience in Action(1987), in which instruments played crucial roles in producing scientific facts. The year 1979 was also when the analytic philosopher Mario Bunge, in “Five Buds of Techno-philosophy,” pronounced that while technologies ought to occupy philosophical attention, to date, he claimed, there had not been a single monograph on the philosophy of technology. But this was also the year of my ownTechnics and Praxis: A Philosophy of Technology(1979), jointly published by the Boston Philosophy of Science and Synthese Library series. It, too, took a praxis turn, with a look at how science is materiallyembodiedin technologies. Later it was cited as the first philosophy of technology book from North America and contained the first English overview of Heidegger's philosophy of technology. And externally, this was also the year of the Iranian revolution, a primary information technology of which was the cassette recorder, which carried the ayatollah's and mullah's messages and which was small and decentralized compared with other media. This miniaturized-decentralized technology is one dimension of the New Technologies.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0321 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0321.xml

Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: Kierkegaard's Silentio focuses attention on the last of God's commands to Abraham, the command to sacrifice Isaac. But he also calls our attention to a couple of the promises that constitute the covenantal relation, the promise of a land and the promise that through his seed all people will be blessed. 27
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0333 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0333.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Is a Hermeneutic Phenomenology Wide Enough? A Ricoeurian Reply to Janicaud's
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.28.3.issue-3
Date: 7 1, 2014
Author(s): Davidson Scott
Abstract: There are two results of this discussion to which I want to draw specific attention. First, this article suggests that commentators on Janicaud's minimal phenomenology, though few, have largely misunderstood the significance of this development. They have taken it to diminish the prestige of phenomenology, to the point of turning it into a trivial enterprise that describes banal phenomena. This can be traced back to the fact that they set up the issue in terms of a contrast between an ambitious maximal phenomenology that tests the limits of the visible and a minimal phenomenology that roots itself firmly within its boundaries. But Janicaud himself already dispels that contrast: his call for a minimal phenomenology does not advocate for a less ambitious or more restrained vision of phenomenology, as if its motto were to “keep costs down, do as little as possible, take no risks.”27 The alternative is not, as commentators have suggested, between either a phenomenology of the invisible or a phenomenology of the visible; instead it concerns two different possible approaches to a phenomenology of the invisible: one that pushes the limits of the visible through a maximal threshold of excess (Marion, Levinas, Henry) and another that pursues those limits through a minimal threshold of sense (Merleau-Ponty, Deleuze). That is the choice that Janicaud bequeaths to phenomenology today.28
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.28.3.0315 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.28.3.0315.xml

Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
Article Title: Recovering Hyperbole:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: philrhet.45.4.issue-4
Date: 12 1, 2012
Abstract: When hyperbole functions in this way it presents a falsehood that is not intended to be deceptive and takes on the form of errancy, that is, possessing “the structureof error without being anerror” (Mileur1990, 113), whereby one can move the audience toward alternate perceptions of truth(s) and reality through the paradox of “erring” (Taylor1984). Hyperbole is “the language of detours, of errancy, extravagance, and even errantry” (Magnus, Stewart, and Mileur1993, 139). It is disorienting to view possible alternate interpretations of truth(s) through this errancy, but as Goran V. Stanivukovic boldly argues, “A [hyperbolic] lie, expressed in linguistic terms, becomes truth on a hermeneutical level” (2007, 17). This lie, or errant formation, presents one with such a radical, exaggerated falsehood that one's attention is arrested. One is not able to resolve the conflict immediately or easily, but the suspicion that something more is being said is heightened.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/philrhet.45.4.0406 journal-article-10.5325_philrhet.45.4.0406.xml

Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
Article Title: “Reading the Past against the Grain: The Shape of Memory Studies.”
Publisher: University of Chicago Press
Issue: philrhet.46.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 1998
Abstract: The moment of configuration occurs uniquely within each individual text, as guided by the interpretive capacities and “productive imagination” of an individual agent or group of agents: the creators of the text. An analysis of this mimetic moment focuses on the variety of ways in which the agent writing history configures the agency, relationships, and temporality of historical subjects within the confines of the text. To draw again on the example of juvenile biographies, some creators may explicitly draw attention to these choices in their texts. Some simply execute their conscious choices in ways that leave subtle marks on the texts. Still others may not be fully aware of their interpretive role, yet their texts nonetheless bear the marks of rhetorical selection and arrangement.9 10
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/philrhet.46.2.0182 journal-article-10.5325_philrhet.46.2.0182.xml

Journal Title: Utopian Studies
Article Title: The Rhetorical Function of Utopia:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: utopianstudies.23.1.issue-1
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: In the first volume of The Principle of Hope, Bloch defines utopia as an “anticipatory consciousness”—the “Not Yet Conscious” as opposed to the “Now.” This is not limited to the content of the unconscious mind but, rather, is refined to mean the creative impulse of what is potentially about to become conscious or actual. This leads in material reality to what Bloch calls the “Not Yet Become.” For Bloch, the material world, like the conscious mind, is constantly in a process of undetermined change and is full of possibility. The utopian dream of a better life is, moreover, a fundamental aspect of being human for Bloch. Like modern, psychological understandings of rhetoric in the twentieth century, the function of utopia for Bloch is the anticipation of a transformed future. This seems to have much to do with identification and motivation, two psychological mechanisms that are behind the workings of rhetoric according to modern rhetorician Kenneth Burke, as we shall see in the next section. For Bloch, utopia is the expression of hope not only as an emotion but as an aspect of collective will and goal-making. Its function is not overtly critical, but it is expressive and instrumental—aligning it with rhetorical praxis and the changing of attitudes. Of course, because it aims to change things for the better, it necessarily draws attention to the shortcomings of current reality, so in this sense it is also critical and ethical.24
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.23.1.0113 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.23.1.0113.xml
